summary:
The Security Council adopted Resolution 2750 (2024) at its 9721st meeting on 11 September 2024. 
The Security Council recalled its previous resolutions concerning Sudan and reaffirmed its strong commitment to Sudan's unity, sovereignty, independence, and territorial integrity. 
It emphasized the importance of protecting civilians and promoting accountability for human rights violations. 
The Council recalled the final report of the Sudan Panel of Experts and took note of letters from the Secretary-General and the Government of Sudan. 
It recognized the need for fair procedures for delisting individuals and entities designated under resolution 1591 (2005). 
The Council determined that the situation in Sudan continues to threaten international peace and security. 
Acting under Chapter VII of the UN Charter, it renewed measures imposed by previous resolutions, including arms embargo and travel bans, until 12 September 2025. 
The Council decided to review the measures again by 12 September 2025 and recalled the provisions of resolution 2725 (2024), and decided to remain seized of the matter.
